awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Spin Correlations and Spin-Orbit Effects in New Quantum Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports collaborative research and educational activities carried out among theory groups at Ohio University and the University of Florida, working in close connection with scientists in Argentina and Brazil, to combine techniques and expertise and tackle important and topical problems in materials research.  The project will focus on exploring electronic properties of materials where the electron's spin degree of freedom is strongly affected by their spatial (orbital) motion.  The coupling of spin and orbital degrees of freedom is a recently rediscovered phenomenon that has been observed to impact a number of properties in metals, semiconductors, and insulators, and can be enhanced by applied electric fields.  The research to be carried out is designed to provide a widely applicable description of how spin-orbit interactions compete with repulsive electron-electron interactions under different external fields and microscopic environments.  This description will be applied to decorated or intercalated graphene (a two-dimensional material made of carbon atoms that is one atom thick), other two-dimensional single crystals, and three-dimensional materials in which the energy of the electronic excitations is linearly proportional to their momentum.  The project is expected to provide fundamental insights into the consequences of spin-orbit interactions as well as to advance the understanding of materials for better experimental characterization and eventual device applications in magnetism, spin-sensitive electronics, and quantum information processing.  The project team also plans a number of educational activities across its different sites, including the training of junior researchers in the US and Latin America, as well as outreach efforts that bring in writers to produce engaging books for a general K-12 audience on topics related to the research.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award will support theoretical research and educational activities aimed at achieving a fundamental understanding of spin-orbit interactions and their competition with Coulomb repulsion in recently discovered materials that include graphene and its derivatives, two-dimensional dichalcogenides and Kagome crystals, three-dimensional Dirac semimetals, and their heterostructures.  In addition to their fascinating and somewhat exotic physical properties, these materials promise a variety of exciting technological applications, from magnetics and spintronics to new carbon-based devices, and even quantum information processing. The project team plans to employ and further develop appropriate theoretical techniques, including the numerical renormalization group, the density-matrix renormalization group, and continuous and tight-binding scattering-matrix approaches, as well as field-theoretical representations of low-energy effective Hamiltonians for the systems of interest. These approaches are proven and reliable in treating strongly correlated problems, and their complementarity gives the collaboration a unique advantage.  The research team consisting of theory groups at Ohio University and the University of Florida, working in close collaboration with scientists in Argentina and Brazil, will seek to advance the techniques to enhance their range of applicability, especially in connection with time-dependent and non-equilibrium phenomena.  Competition between phases of matter, and their control and modification through external probes, are the two main issues to be investigated. A particular focus will be on understanding and guiding experimental developments, with the goal of elucidating the role that intrinsic quantum symmetries play in the presence of external electromagnetic and strain fields.  The project team also plans a number of educational activities across its different sites, including the training of junior researchers in the US and Latin America, as well as outreach efforts that bring in writers to produce engaging books for a general K-12 audience on topics related to the research.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported research at the University of Florida (under award DMR-1508122) and at Ohio University (under award DMR-1508325). The research also involved collaborative research with scientists at academic institutions in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Germany, and Mexico.

The project involved theoretical research and educational activities related to the effects of spin correlations and spin-orbit interactions in various classes of solids. The focus was on understanding and guiding experimental developments in layered materials and in engineered nanostructures. We also explored related concepts in the physics of strongly correlated bulk materials such as heavy fermions.

A major intellectual goal was to advance understanding of the role played by local environments and time-dependent effects on the electronic properties of newly discovered quantum materials.  Much of the research focused on quasi-two-dimensional materials like graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides, with high potential for device applications, and on the identification of phenomena involving strong electron-electron interactions. Although present in all materials, repulsion between the mobile electrons plays a remarkably small role in simple metals such as copper and aluminum. However, the effects of such interactions can be greatly enhanced (and even become the dominant feature) in systems of reduced spatial dimensionality (such as quantum dots or wires) or containing localized magnetic moments. Theoretical efforts addressed the effects on electronic and magnetic properties of material systems, introduced by juxtaposing different materials, mechanical deformations, time-dependent mechanical and optical driving, and conditions for the appearance of novel magnetic phases, among other topics.

Our studies of layered materials revealed the importance of crystalline symmetries and relativistic effects giving rise to spin-orbit interactions that couple the electron spin (the quintessential magnetic property) with its spatial path as it moves through the crystal. From our studies on mechanical deformations of membranes such as monolayer graphene, we learned how mechanical perturbations can modify the electric charge distribution in a reversible manner and affect the adsorption of molecules, making possible to use the same material either as an electrical insulator or as a conductor.

Another thrust of the project focused on different phases (i.e., regimes featuring distinct physical properties such as conducting vs insulating or magnetic vs nonmagnetic) arising in systems with strong electron-electron correlations. Much of the work focused on "magnetic impurity models," simplified settings for which it is possible to complete rigorous theoretical and numerical results. Of particular interest are magnetic impurity models that can be tuned from one phase to another at the absolute zero of temperature by varying a nonthermal parameter such as applied pressure.

One significant achievement of the project was the elucidation of the spatial structure of the quantum-mechanical wave function around a magnetic impurity atom as the system is tuned from a phase in which the local magnetic moment is collectively screened by the electrons in the host metal (a phenomenon known as the Kondo effect) to a different phase in which the local moment is unscreened (and the Kondo effect is said to be destroyed). A Kondo-destruction transition has been predicted to occur when magnetic atoms are adsorbed on monolayer graphene. It also serves as a theoretical paradigm for a class of phase transitions seen in heavy-fermion materials (metals that contain elements such as Ce or U with unpaired electrons in their 4f or 5f shells). Another achievement of the project was the demonstration that Kondo-destruction transitions promote the appearance of superconductivity in their vicinity, consistent with observations in CeRhIn5, which has the highest superconducting transition temperature among all Ce-based heavy-fermion systems.

One of the most important aspects of the project was the education and training of future scientists who played fundamental parts in the research. Undergraduates and graduate students were mentored in research skills, prepared and presented talks at scientific meetings, participated as coauthors on peer-reviewed publications in high-impact journals, and gained first-hand experience of the collaborative and international nature of much contemporary science. Several participating graduate students completed their PhD dissertations under the auspices of this project and move on to positions at academic institutions or government laboratories in the USA or abroad.
